title: Tony Abbott warns balance between security and freedom may shift â politics live | World news | The Guardian
summary: national security positioning : a quick analysis .
tony abbott addresses parliament on national security : restrictions on some , protections for others .
george brandis addresses reporters on the security reforms : sunset clauses to remain .

documents.title: politics , this monday evening
text: i think that will do us for today .
i have a task to attend to that requires me to devote my attention elsewhere for the next few hours , so forgive the slightly early exit .
thanks muchly for your company today , as ever and to brilliant bowers , as ever , for his contributions .
i 'll be back at the usual time in the morning .

let 's wrap the day , monday : the coalition repositioned slightly on national security in an effort to hold parliamentary consensus , pledging that new laws would not allow asio agents to torture terrorism suspects ; and agreeing that some of the controversial powers would be subject to sunset clauses .
much ado was made about enhanced parliamentary security in canberra .
but business went on as normal , more or less , apart from seeing armed police in the coffee queues and on the ring road , and restricted access to some areas of the building .
both tony abbott and bill shorten made separate statements to parliament on national security .
abbott warned the voters the government would be ( repeat , would be ) trading personal freedom for public safety .
sorry , but that 's how things had to be .

shorten warned abbott that labor would support the coming iraq incursion provided four conditions were met ; and back in an expansion of police and asio powers provided there was scrutiny and oversight .
there was not a blank cheque .
well , not entirely blank , anyway .
a couple of scribbles on it .
both leaders then congratulated each other for not playing politics with important subjects , like geopolitics and public safety .
there was more , but those were the key developments .
big day tomorrow .
some parliamentary debate on tranche one of the terror laws two party room meetings to consider more national security reforms .
the prime minister off to the united nations to discuss foreign fighters .
big day .
see you all then .
we did expect a final arbitration in peter slipper 's legal proceedings in canberra this afternoon .
( slipper is the former liberal mp , independent and house speaker convicted by the act magistrates court for misusing entitlements . )
the final result has been held over until wednesday .

documents.title: national security positioning : a quick analysis
text: it 's worth pausing to reflect on the two contributions today on national security from tony abbott and bill shorten .
the build on this issue has been , thus far , rhetorical .
we 've been talking about national security now for some months .
the coalition moved quite deliberately to change the conversation post budget .
the change in the national conversation coincides with the specific intelligence of a specific ( potential ) threat that ultimately prompted last week 's police raids in sydney and brisbane .
politics will of course keep right on talking .
but now we are moving into practical business .

with parliament about to legislate policy changes that will significantly expand the powers of australia 's intelligence agencies at the expense of personal freedoms abbott is offering voters this formulation .
the delicate balance between freedom and security may have to shift .
there may be more restrictions on some , so that there can be more protection for others .
it 's interesting , that need to explain .
once , you could have just flicked the national security switch in politics and face precious little dissent in this country , which has a deeply conservative reflex .
australians like to think we are larrikins but the mythology of our dissent lives larger than the practice .
but this is the post snowden era .
there is a level of unease about the extent and reach of the security apparatus that has trickled down into popular culture , and privacy feels increasingly an outmoded and anachronistic concept .
what was once an uncomplicated plus for a conservative governments the resort to the tin hat is now more complex .

the complexity of the political terrain should n't be overstated of course , i 've been saying for some time national security is much stronger ground for the coalition politically than the budget debacle .
but i 've also been saying over the past few months abbott has got to be very careful not to overplay his hand .
he 's damaged himself on trust issues because of broken election promises .
appearing completely cynical here would only compound the damage .

the howard era has also bequeathed a mixed blessing on national security issues the message frame worked for the former coalition government post 9/11 , but over reach prompted the cycle to peak and then flame out .
the domestic national security environment has shifted for australia and other liberal democracies courtesy of the conflagrations in the middle east .
the extent of the shift is arguable , but it 's reasonable to assert there 's been a shift .
military engagement in iraq , whatever the current official explanations , will likely increase the security risks at home .
history suggests that it will , whatever the current official protestations to the contrary .
engagement in iraq is a leap into the unknown .
with all that noted , the looming legislative changes are a big deal .
let me repeat that a big deal .
there is a serious expansion of police and agency powers in contemplation .

the reforms also have a broad consumer dimension when we get to the mandatory retention of people 's personal communications metadata , that touches australians across the board and prompts them to think about their privacy expectations in a digital world .
the changes are big enough to prompt abbott to pause and explain not just roll forward on the assumption the voters are cheerily running behind him .
shorten 's contribution today in parliament had more texture that the superficial effusions of bipartisanship suggest .
on iraq , the labor leader laid out the specific conditions attached to labor supporting an intensification militarily .
the message to abbott here is this far and no further .
on security , the message is also more shaded .
shorten says labor is inclined to be cooperative , but again , do n't push us or this too far .
oversight is important .
scrutiny is important .
i suspect , at the end of the day , not important enough to have a huge barny about , but important enough to frame at the outset .
an interesting political dance between these two leaders , at this moment , right now .
some off broadway chamber shots now from bowers , bless his cotton socks .
i 'll do this post , then i want to think about the respective national security statements with some analysis .
note the new screens in the chamber .
spiffy .
helpful too , if you nod off and forget where you are .

the prime minister tony abbott makes a statement on national security before question time in the house of representatives this afternoon , monday 22nd september 2014 photograph by mike bowers for the guardian australia bowers i loved this one .
hai hai .

the member for maranoa bruce scott greets a visiting samoan parliamentary delegation during question time in the house of representatives this afternoon , monday 22nd september 2014 photograph by mike bowers for the guardian australia bowers
abbott has called time on question time .
bridie jabour has kindly contributed this update on the question of whether or not the government is about to switch course on its budget welfare measures .
this issue was referenced during question time in the house .
here 's ms bridie : the government is staying coy on potential amendments to legislation which introduces sweeping changes to australia 's welfare system .
the two social services bills are due to be debated in the senate tomorrow , in the midst of a week which is shaping up to be all about security measures .
the sunday telegraph reported the government has agreed to scrap the changes to indexation of family payments and pension which would see them reduced in real terms .

labor has welcomed the changes but will not pass the bills if they still contain stripping under-30s of income support for six months at a time and putting them on six month waiting lists , among other measures .
the government is not actually confirming the concessions and today , senator mitch fifield echoed the treasurer 's remarks yesterday , do n't believe everything you read in the newspapers .
fifield was asked in senate question time if the government was considering amendments .

this was his reply : the government remains committed to all social security measures , the opposition has even signalled support for savings measures around family tax benefits a and b , the opposition would be wise to get facts straight rather than relying on newspaper reports .
we are also committed to ensuring sustainability of the welfare system , the opposition should be supporting these common sense measures .
chamber channel surfing means i missed the ejection of labor 's jenny macklin for the crime of attempting to table a document .
actually i think it was the crime of not taking her seat when madam speaker asked her to .
labor has stuck with the indigenous cuts in the second half of question time .
abbott : members opposite ca n't help themselves .
they think that more money is the answer to every single problem .
the reality is that if there have been any cuts in this particular area , they are cuts put in place by the former government .
my colleague bridie jabour is in the red room .
labor is a bit more feisty there .
she 's sent me a short update .
the opposition senate leader penny wong opened question time wanting to know when exactly the request for australia 's help to fight islamic state took place .
she also wanted to know what form the request took .
the government senate leader , eric abetz , was unable to advise the senate about those details .
he took the question on notice .
labor 's doug cameron is interested in the costs of the conflict .

finance minister mathias cormann would not be drawn : what i am in a position to confirm is the government will provide updates on the fiscal impact of the engagement in international action against isil in the usual way , through regular budget updates .
abbott takes a dorothy dixer to thank his hosts in north arnhem land last week .
he says he will continue to spend a week in a remote community while he remains in public life .
shorten congratulates abbott on his recent northern exposure .
shorten would like to know whether he will now restore the half billion he cut from indigenous programs in the budget .
not so much , says abbott .
there have been some modest reductions in funding for some programs but i think the leader of the opposition will find that overall , indigenous spending continues to increase every year .
the prime minister says the cuts the intergration of programs into his department were supported by the indigenous advisory council .
i am very confident that we can get a better result for the indigenous people of australia with the changes that we have announced .
that is my determination to get better results through more efficiency , more focus and more targetting in this spending .
less cash .
more results .
do the maths .
it was a little hard to follow but i think bob katter was concerned , simultaneously , about the defacing of a mosque and about the government 's skilled migration policies .
this question is for scott morrison , the immigration minister .
morrison has to swim along a complicated rip of logic .
he 's not happy about defacing mosques .
he 's happy about skilled migration policies , which are non-discriminatory .
morrison : what we are looking for is for people to come and join this team , people who will contribute to this country and that is the success and history of immigration in this country .
that is what will produce cohesion and that is why i join with the member in condemning the sorts of attacks that he has just referred to in his question .
they are an abomination to the way of life that we stand for in this country .

the immigration policies that we have crafted over generations will be continued by this government because they are producing economic and social dividends for this country and they are designed to produce unity not division .
katter is having a shout .
the member for kennedy bob katter during question time in the house of representatives this afternoon , monday 22nd september 2014 bowers guardian australia
labor 's jenny macklin .

q : given the government is planning to defer its harsh cuts to pensions , families and young job seekers for now , will the prime minister now guarantee he will not reintroduce these harsh cuts in the future ?
abbott : madam speaker , i really find it hard to understand exactly what point the shadow minister is trying to make here .
unlike members opposite , when we make a commitment to the australian people , we keep it , so we stand by all the measures in the budget .

but we absolutely accept that budget measures do need to go through the parliament and that is why we are prepared to talk to all constructive people in this parliament to do what is necessary to get labor 's debt and deficit disaster back under control .
( translation : back to that key theme of the day .
everything in canberra is true and factual right up until the moment when it is n't .
abbott is acknowledging here that most of the budget is doomed , but he 's making a pitch to salvage some alternatives .
for the record , there was some chamber chortling at the line about keeping promises . )

documents.title: question time
text: pushing ahead .
the questions from labor thus far have been when are you going to dump that wicked nasty budget .
some news reports suggest you will .
abbott responds by saying the government is open for business on the budget .
let 's talk , bill , about budget sustainability .

i do n't think it is too late for members opposite to have an attack of common sense and a vision of the long term national interest and that is why this government is prepared to talk even to the labor party .
if it is necessary , in order to do the right thing by the people of this country , we will talk to the labor party .
a chamber shot before i catch us up with question time .

the prime minister tony abbott makes a statement on national security before question time in the house of representatives this afternoon , monday 22nd september 2014 bowers guardian australia regrettably for some time to come , the delicate balance between freedom and security may have to shift .
there may be more restrictions on some , so that there can be more protection for others .
shorten rounds out his contribution by saying iraq must be the architect of its own destiny .
peace ca n't be imposed from without .
it must be built from within .
he says australia must safeguard its multiculturalism in the current environment .
it is a miracle of modern australia .
we should never make the millions of australians who have become australians people from every nation and from every faith feel less safe or less welcome .
we will not overcome hatred with hatred , we will not overcome intolerance by being intolerant .
shorten advises people to keep their ill temper or prejudice about islam to themselves .
the leader of the opposition bill shorten makes a reply to prime minister tony abbott 's statement on national security before question time in the house of representatives this afternoon .
bowers/guardian australia then national security reforms .
labor is on board , but there must be a balance .
labor will continue to ensure that the national security imperative is appropriately balanced with the importance of protecting our democratic freedoms .
parliamentary scrutiny and oversight of those proposals is essential .
shorten says this is not 2003 .
let us be clear about the differences between the situation in iraq today and the conflict that labor opposed in 2003 .
the 2003 war was based on a flawed premise of false information .
it was a war embarked upon without a meaningful plan to win the peace .
in part , it created some of the conditions that have necessitated this international response .
it was a war against a hostile iraqi government without the support of the united nations and the international community .
as labor said that that time , the foundations for military intervention were simply not there .
however , today , a democratically elected national unity government of iraq is seeking help from the international community to protect its people from genocide and other mass atrocities .
today we are part of an international effort that includes countries from the region as the pm has said .
we are fulfilling our responsibility as a good international citizen , our duty as a humanitarian peace-loving nation .
shorten says labor would prefer negotiation over conflict , but there is no option for negotiation .
you ca n't negotiate with an irrational actor like islamic state .
we do want our australian military personnel to carry out a clearly defined mission in iraq at the request of the iraqi government and then come home safely .
military involvement to achieve humanitarian objectives is not our first instinct and it is never our preferred solution to geopolitical problems .
but we recognise that sometimes there is simply no alternative .
put plainly , we can not negotiate with isil because there is nothing rational about what they seek to do .
isil and their like wish only to do harm , to spread the bitter hatred that fuels their genocidal intent .
they are a breeding ground for terrorists spent on causing havoc not only in the middle east but throughout australia , throughout the world and in australia and our neighbouring countries .

documents.title: labor leader , bill shorten responds
text: shorten opens on the same bipartisan note .
keeping our people safe is above politics .
the security of our nation runs deeper than our political differences .
he says labor has not offered support for australia 's contribution to the international humanitarian mission to iraq lightly .
sending australians into harm 's way is the most serious of decisions .
our support for the government on this issue is not a matter of nationalism , it is a calculation of conscience and national interest .
shorten nominates four principles underpinning the current bipartisanship when it comes to iraq .
these dot points are direct quotes .
firstly , we have indicated we do not support the deployment of combat units to directly engage in fighting isil .
secondly , australian operations should be confined to the territory of iraq .
thirdly , our involvement should continue only until the iraqi government is in a position to take full responsibility for the security of their nation and their people .
fourthly , if the iraqi government and its forces engage in unacceptable conduct , or adopt unacceptable policies , we should withdraw our support .
abbott rounds out the recitation of dark and uncertain times by calling for national unity .
if , in the weeks and months ahead , australians come to appreciate and savour our unity , as much as our diversity , we will emerge stronger from these difficulties .
and the full stop is about god .
it may be too much to expect that everyone , everywhere might finally accept that every single human being has the same inherent rights and dignity .
it may be too much to expect that everyone everywhere might finally subscribe to the principle of treat others as you would have them treat you .
but it is not too much , surely , to expect that our world might finally and fully grasp that it is never right to kill people because they have a the different view of god .
killing in the name of god is never right .
mistreating others in the name of god is never right .
and if the all but universal revulsion towards the isil horror has this result good might finally emerge , despite the pointless death and dislocation that confronts us now .
abbott addresses the nexus between military involvement iraq and the domestic national security risks .
the prime minister suggests there is no connection between the two events because the is death cultists do n't like us already , because of who we are , not because of our military entanglements .
it is our acceptance that people can live and worship in the way they choose that bothers them , not our foreign policy .
isil kills because it glories in death and because no-one has yet been strong enough to stop it .
it is isil 's success on the battlefield , at least as much as its absolutism , that explains its perverse appeal .
he addresses the counter terrorism raids from last week .
abbott says a terrorist act was imminent .
it was important to respond with great strength to disrupt this imminent terrorist act .
it demonstrates that our determination equals that of those who would do us harm .

we will more than match the resolve of our adversaries in all things accept malice , because our military , police and security personnel have goodwill towards everyone , except those who are plotting to hurt us .
today , i pledge that our security agencies will have all the resources and the authority that they reasonably need .
he then points to the looming legal changes regarding returning foreign fighters .
the only safe place for those who have been brutalised and militarised by fighting with terrorists is inside a maximum security prison .
my unambiguous message to all australians who fight with terrorist groups is that you will be arrested , prosecuted and jailed for a very long time indeed .
our laws are being changed to make it easier to keep potential terrorists off the streets .

documents.title: tony abbott addresses parliament on national security : restrictions on some , protections for others
text: rightio , here is the prime minister 's statement to parliament on national security .
he opens by thanking labor for its efforts to be bipartisan for standing shoulder to shoulder with the government against people who would do australia harm .
abbott articulates his government 's core principles .
first , the give will do whatever is possible to keep people safe .
second , our security measures at home and abroad are directed against terrorism not religion .
third , australians should always live normally because terrorists ' goal is to scare us out of being ourselves .
then recent events .
as we all know , there have been major anti-terrorist raids across sydney and brisbane .
our police and security agencies will always strive to stay at least one step ahead of those who would do us harm and so far , thank god , they have succeeded .
i ca n't promise that hideous events will never take place on australian soil .
but i can promise , that we will never stoop to the level of those who hate us and fight evil with evil .
then a new construction .
some will have their freedoms curtailed ( courtesy of the government 's counter terror measures ) in order to protect others .
regrettably , for some time to come , australians will have to endure more security than we 're used to and more inconvenience than we would like .
regrettably for some time to come , the delicate balance between freedom and security may have to shift .
there may be more restrictions on some , so that there can be more protection for others .
after all , the most basic freedom of all is the freedom to walk the streets unharmed and to sleep safe in our beds at night .
creating new offences that are harder to beat on a technicality may be a small price to pay for saving lives and for maintaining the social fabric of an open , free and multicultural nation .

one more worthy offering in the mix today which i neglected in the post before last , crikey 's bernard keane is reporting that the afp has been gagged by the government from commenting on the link between prime minister tony abbott 's decision to return to war in iraq and the increased terrorism threat .
keane says the afp has declined to answer specific questions on this subject , referring inquiries to brandis ' department .
that piece is paywalled .
the context is asio has said recently that australia 's involvement in iraq does n't increase the domestic national security threat risk .
experience from 2003 suggests otherwise .
former afp head mick keelty dared to suggest a link between the two things in 2004 and was soundly slapped by the howard government for his pains .
also , just an acknowledgement of the lively conversation in the comments thread .
i 've had a quick whip down .
have n't had a moment to contribute as yet .
may get there after question time .
thanks for the contributions .
just before we hit security statements and question time some thinkiness to come back to at your leisure .
paula matthewson has a good piece on the drum today about shorten and the virtues of adopting a constructively-negative approach to opposition .
i like that construction , it 's food for thought .
it might not quite lead to peace in our time , but it may well lead to the kinder , gentler polity that until recently has been little more than a wistfully muttered ideal .
i 'd also recommend a fine column by constitutional law expert george williams in fairfax today .

this piece pushes back against a really insidious framing which is emerging in the debate about recognising indigenous australians in the constitution : this framing alleges the australian people will never accept a discrimination clause in the constitution .
this is a contention .
it 's not , actually , a fact , yet it is being presented too often as a fact .
a single clause prohibiting racial discrimination is not any form of bill of rights , nor could the high court turn it into one .
it would simply add another protection to the list of one-off rights already in the constitution , such as those for freedom of religion and trial by jury .
the change would hardly be radical .
the news cycle is a funny old business .
and by funny , i mean arbitrary .
it 's been clear from the get go that tranche one of the coalition 's terror package contains provisions allowing asio agents to use force without consequences during operations .
we 've reported on this pretty extensively .
yet this only became a thing when the word torture was used .
i 'm obviously not sanguine about torture .
not in the least .

but it would be interesting to be able to comprehend readily why the use of force without consequences ( by people who previously have not been either trained or authorised to use it ) was n't really a thing , but torture is a thing .
obviously the simple answer is orders of magnitude getting knocked to the ground or tasered or restrained with force or assaulted is different to being waterboarded .
as david leyonhjelm noted today torture is a totemic issue .
in any case , torture is now off the table .
the last asio boss , david irvine , was asked about force when he appeared before parliament 's intelligence committee in mid august .
why did asio need scope to use force ?
why did it need to give its agents immunity from prosecution ?
why not just bring along police who are actually trained to use force in apprehending suspects ?
irvine said a couple of things .
he said operations undertaken by the intelligence services sail close to the wind in terms of breaking existing laws .
( just give yourself a moment to reflect on that statement . )
giving immunity to agents working undercover was a necessary protection to safeguard national security , he argued .
irvine said some operations were so sensitive that asio simply did not want police present .
simply , there may be operations with a particular level of sensitivity where it would not be appropriate to have law enforcement along .
simon cullen ( @ simon cullen ) the ch 9 publicly pic for tomorrow night 's interview between @ twitterid & @ twitterid : so many political books this year are people buying them ?
or are all these tomes cutting one another 's lunch ?

documents.title: politics this lunchtime
text: let 's take stock before the afternoon us up and drops us in the merry old land of oz .
or somewhere less trippy .
monday , thus far : it 's terror week .
yes i know last week was terror week but in canberra , it 's still terror week .
the prime minister is expected to provide a national security update just before question time .
the labor leader , bill shorten , shall respond to the update .
in addition to the prime minister 's update , the attorney-general george brandis has made two concessions concerning his counter terror packages .
he 'll outlaw torture by asio agents in tranche one ( happy days ) ; and he 'll put sunset clauses back into tranche two .

in between the various concessions , he 's arguing something that looks ( to silly non-wigged mortals ) rather like a reverse onus of proof is nothing of the kind and , ps : why is everyone going on about reversing the onus of proof anyhow almost like someone in the government ( whose surname rhymes with zandis ) said that 's what the coalition was considering .
( the eternal why , right there . )
back to semi-normal transmission .
labor is reserving its position on tranche two of the terror package until it sees the exposure draft .
tranche one , with various amendments , is now pretty much a done deal .

outside , in the world , well , not the real world , but the world according to [ insert xxx ] , former prime ministers are engaged in various acts of look at moi ' in order to sell books and settle scores and provide official histories .
tasmanian independent andrew wilkie is also settling some scores of his own about events in 2003 .
there are also some police about , here in the parliamentary precinct .
welcome chaps , nice to see you .
give them a wave if you happen to cruise along on the ring road .
business , meanwhile , is carrying on much as usual .
over .
one more moment 's housekeeping .
the senate was expected to embark on debate on the first tranche of the terror laws today .
it 's been put back until tomorrow .
brandis informed journalists earlier the delay accommodates the wishes of the opposition .
history wars .
the whistleblower versus the prime minister .

independent mp andrew wilkie at a press conference in parliament house , canberra on monday 22nd september 2014 bowers howard during his sunday night interview rejected emphatically a direct connection between the botched invasion in 2003 and the security situation on the ground in norther iraq today .

howard : if you 're seeking to locate the responsibilities [ for the situations in iraq and syria ] specifically to the 2003 invasion , let me put to you syria was not involved in any outside military operation so much of the islamic state operation comes out of what is occurring in syria , and to suggest that it 's purely or predominantly a result of what happened in iraq in 2003 is a false reading of history .
from terror laws to iraq .
john howard last night said he was embarrassed to learn that countries including australia had invaded iraq in 2003 based on faulty intelligence .
the tasmanian independent andrew wilkie ( a former intelligence analyst who quit his post over the iraq imbroglio ) does n't care a jot about howard 's embarrassment .
he cares about dead people in iraq , and dead soldiers sent on a dud mission , and the consequences of botched regime change .
wilkie sprints right down the long run : howard should n't be out rewriting history , the mp contends that he should actually be in the dock at the icc .
wilkie : look frankly i 'm disappointed that the prosecutor at the international criminal court has n't thought to hold john howard responsible for conspiracy to commit mass murder .

because one thing to take australia to war based on a lie , it makes it all the worse when that war has been so damaging to so many people and remains in the opinion of a great many historians as the darkest blot on this nation 's history , at least in modern times , as far as foreign policy and security goes .
what john howard is doing is cherry- the the information and trying to rewrite history .

wilkie says howard ( and the allies who took the decision to invade iraq ) is responsible for the rise of islamic state : the circumstances in iraq today are a direct result of the anarchy and the security vacuum that was created , that was created in this country as a result of eleven and a half years of war , a war that was started in part by the australian government and john howard in particular .
if we had not gone to war eleven and a half years ago , and destroyed that country and created this security vacuum , then the circumstances would not exist for islamic state to have emerged .
so yes , they are responsible .
we will chase up john howard to allow an opportunity for comment .

the attorney-general george brandis with the new director general of asio duncan lewis at a press conference in the blue room of parliament house in canberra , monday 22nd september 2014 mike bowers for guardian australia bowers god save me from the tyranny of small , stupid people and their questions .
next .

karen middleton from sbs wants to know , concerning the looming foreign fighters legislation , how something that looks an awful lot like a reverse onus of proof and works like a reverse onus of proof is not a reverse onus of proof .
george brandis sc tries , manfully , not to sigh at the manifest ignorance arrayed before him on this fine monday morning .

q : you 're saying that the prosecution need only prove that someone is in a declared area and then there is a burden of proof on the defence to prove why they were there , and to prove they were there for a reason reason .
if there is a shared burden of proof or even a larger burden of proof on the defence how is that not a reversal of the onus of proof ?
brandis : it 's the most commonplace thing in criminal law for there to be an offence and defences .
the crown or the prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the offence has been committed .

if an accused person then wants to raise a defence , then they have obviously a need , what lawyers call an evidentiary burden , to put material before the court to show that they come within the meaning of that defence .
that 's never been regarded as a reversal of the onus of proof .
the director-general declines to add to those remarks .
on the perils of simple minded analysis .
q : last week the police raids they have n't resulted in a lot of specific charges or court action .
did the police disrupt a sophisticated network with international links or just a couple of guys talking with some friends overseas ?

brandis : well , the director-general might like to add to my remarks , but let me just make this point : the reason this operation was such a significant operation is because the network that was disrupted presented a very serious threat to the domestic security of australia and the safety of australians .
and one should n't make the simple-minded mistake of assuming that because so far there has only been one arrest for a significant terrorism offence , that the operation was not justified .
the man who was arrested was the principal focus of the operation .
the police acting on the advice of the intelligence agencies acted because it was necessary to act to protect the public from imminent harm .
they acted very effectively .
very professionally .
very swiftly .
and i think gave the public the reassurance that we do have the capability as well as the will to act when we need to act to protect the public .

documents.title: george brandis addresses reporters on the security reforms : sunset clauses to remain
text: the attorney-general is now in the blue room .
standing alongside him is the new top spy , duncan lewis .
lewis has replaced the retiring david irvine at asio .
hard to remember a time when a clandestine person has been so ubiquitous a good development , this , in my view .

the attorney-general george brandis with the new director general of asio duncan lewis at a press conference in the blue room of parliament house in canberra , monday 22nd september 2014 mike bowers for the guardian australia bowers brandis is giving a timetable for the events this week .
brandis notes that the first tranche of legislation is already in the parliament .
the second tranche , the foreign fighters package , will go through the coalition partyroom tomorrow .
then it will be given to the opposition .
then the bill will be released to the media before the introduction to parliament on wednesday .
then it will go to the intelligence committee .
then after a quickie inquiry it will be back to parliament for a vote in the next sitting fortnight .
brandis also tips his hat to the islamic community .
the government had proposed to get rid of provisions which sunset preventive detention orders and control orders .
there was significant push back to this during a period of community consulations .
these provisions will now sunset in 2o25 .
the foreign fighters legislation will be also subject to a 10-year sunsetting provision that can be considered by a future government in a decade 's time , brandis says .
that is a concession .
there 's another one .
brandis says he will ensure the looming legislation expressly prohibits torture .
there has been a debate over the past week over whether a new force provision in tranche one will allow asio agents to torture suspects it up on counter terror raids .
the attorney-general says this is a complete beat up , a red herring .
asio does n't torture people .
it does n't happen , he says .
but he will put it beyond doubt .
brandis : i do n't want the discussion of this important issue to be diverted by an issue that is effectively a red herring .

so this morning in consultation with the director-general and in consultation with the prime minister , i 've decided to add an explicit prohibition in relation to torture so far as concerns special intelligence operations .
he had no choice but to amend the bill .
labor made it clear it would n't pass it in its current form .
back to the building , briefly .

a colleague kindly points out that the prime minister last week addressed the boneheaded decision to downgrade security in parliament house ( to save $ 2.50 ) which predates the more recent decision to essentially lock down the building .
i missed that .
here 's the exchange , for the record .
q : are you aware that there has been chatter about an attack on parliament house and is security there being beefed up ?
abbott : yes , there certainly has been chatter amongst the terrorist support networks of an attack on government and government people and parliament house has been specifically mentioned .

as a result a week or so back there was an urgent review of security at the national parliament and subsequent to that we are placing the australian federal police in charge of security , not just outside the building but inside the building as well .
q : in the light of that then it makes the decision earlier this year to downgrade security at parliament house look pretty daft .
abbott : well , once we were aware that there was the prospect of parliament house being specifically targeting , we acted swiftly .
the odd couple .
okedokes .
the attorney-general george brandis will give a press conference shortly .
i did warn you this was book week .
with julia gillard due to front 60 minutes tomorrow evening , nine publicity is now distributing what it regards as some key quotes from the interview .
a teaser in order to try and build up an audience for the show .
if you are absolutely desperate to have the network 's judgment of key moments from the looming interview here are the quotes , in full , devoid of context , for the record .
former australian prime minister julia gillard will answer your questions on achieving global education .

rex /newspix on the night she told kevin rudd she would challenge him for the leadership : the way i tell it in the book is my side of it ¦ you know¦a very emotional time , if anything the accusations against me in politics and you still read in the newspapers you know the woman who wielded the knife , if anything the reputation i have from that night is one of political brutality .
actually in the moment i was hesitant , a conversation went too long , i certainly fed ( rudd ) hope .
i should n't have done that .
on kevin rudd after she had deposed him : i thought his reaction would be one of hurt and acute distress .
i know a lot now about what it feels like to lose the prime ministership , so i expected him to feel very , very battered and bruised .
obviously i was wrong about that .
on her decision to campaign as the real julia : i put my hand up for that one hundred per cent .
that 's my fault you know sort of dumb , dumb error , rookie error maybe .
i mean i was n't a rookie in politics , i was a rookie at being prime minister .

on the odd couple - her relationship with tim : you look at all of that and you say , how much of that is gender working , because would we think it was quite so odd if a male prime minister or a male chief executive officer of a big bank or whatever had a wife who worked as a hairdresser ?
would we think that was kind of you know really , really odd ?
why on earth did he marry her ?
she 's a hairdresser !
i just do n't think it would occur to us .
i think it was the gender thing a bit .
but in terms of you know being supportive , tim was there and , yes , there 's the blow-drying of the hair , but there 's so much more .
on why she has n't married tim : it 's just the right decision for us and the right decision for me .
we 've just been joking about it , the various descriptors you can put on my forehead , i am an atheist , i 'm not a person of faith , and so i do n't think about marriage in that religious sense .
and i do n't feel that we need you know some ceremony or anything to you know make our relationship meaningful ; it is meaningful .
so it 's the right choice for us .
on life at the lodge and kirribilli : i 'd had no life experience that prepared me for having ah staff around you in that close , intimate sense that staff in the lodge or kirribilli are .
and i thought there 's only a couple of ways of reacting to this .
you could pretend you were poncing around in downton abbey or something like that !
or you could just try and embrace it and make it an extended kind of family circumstance .
on same sex marriage : i 've got what may be in the modern age a kind of old-fashioned , feminist view about can we , take the traditional institution of marriage and stretch it ?
or do you create some other way of solemnising relationships and recognising them as of worth and status .
and when i was a young feminist i would 've said overwhelming the gay community was on that track too , but things have changed !
i accept the course of human history now is that ah we are going to see same sex marriage here and in you know most parts of the developed world .
down in the house , liberal mp dan tehan the affable chair of parliament 's joint intelligence and security committee is tabling a couple of reports .
he 's recommending australian intelligence agencies not be subject to the efficiency dividend .
( that would be another financial boon after the $ 600m the agencies up recently as part of the government 's counter terror package . )
tehan is also rubber stamping the government 's decision to list boko haram and islamic state as terrorist organisations .
he 's being backed in by anthony byrne labor 's most senior member on that committee .
the bells are ringing , the chambers are gathering .
the speaker , bronwyn bishop , is making a statement regarding security in the building .
just in case anyone has missed the security in the building .
occupants are unlikely to have missed the security in the building .
security in the building .
security in the building .
upgraded security measures around the ministerial wing of parliament house , canberra this morning , monday 22nd september 2014 .
photograph by mike bowers for guardian australia .
bowers no reference is made to the recent decision to wind back security in the building .
security in the building .
security in the building .
security in the building .
the ministerial wing of parliament house , canberra this morning , monday 22nd september 2014 .
photograph by mike bowers for guardian australia .
bowers no point in advocating toning this right down , is there ?
no point at all in advocating doing more and talking less .
of course politics tragics will be aware this week is book week .
political book week .
in fact this has been political book year .
last night , we were treated to john howard reflecting on his years in public life as part of the public relations effort to flog his new book about menzies .
tomorrow it will be julia gillard 's turn .
her book is out this week .
it struck me last night , watching the janet albrechtson interview with howard on seven last night how hard it is to shake politicians out of their pat formulations .
former prime minister john howard attends the official opening of the john howard reading room ' at the unsw canberra in canberra .
lukas coch aap coch/aapimage it is so hard to extract genuine moments of spontaneous reflection .
howard has been producing the same formulations , more or less , for the entire period of his public life .
he just adds a new formulation when a new moment presents itself .
this is not to say howard is insincere or confected .
he 's actually a very skilled political communicator .
he 's head and shoulders above the current generation strutting and fretting on the political stage .
it 's just the discipline he imposes on himself : to say within the message frames he sets for himself .
understandable .
but irritating , too .
senator lazarus upon entering the building this morning apparently declined to contribute to a conversation his colleague , jacqui lambie , appears intent on having about sharia law .
the brick with ties said he did n't know very much about sharia law , therefore he would n't express a view .
this chap is obviously as eccentric as mark dreyfus , who this morning expressed a desire to read something prior to giving his opinion on it .
fairfax is reporting that clive palmer is declining to back lambie 's frolic on sharia law .
lively , that pup kennel .
mike bowers snapped pup senator glenn lazarus popping into work this morning .
note the couple of gentlemen plod packing heat and hovering nonchalantly in the background .
let 's do a live cross .
actually , let 's not .
pup senator glenn lazarus at the senate doors this morning with upgraded security in the form of afp officers .
monday 22nd september 2014 .
bowers guardian australia there has been a deal of borderline hysterical reporting about the new security conditions at parliament house for this sitting fortnight .
a couple of things i ca n't quite fathom : why politicians would be speaking publicly about parliament house as a terror target .
parliament house is always a target .
i ca n't recall previous times when we 've all gathered in a circle to have a big public conversation about it .
i can see how that conversation enhances a particular narrative , but i really ca n't see how it serves any genuine public interest .
i suspect it makes the security task at the house more complex for the people charged with doing it .
and it creates concern for the families of people who work in the building .
i repeat , for what purpose ?
if there 's an incident here , god forbid , it wo n't actually be headed off or made less likely by having a big hand wringing conversation about it .
just for the record , it feels business as usual in here this morning .
there are more police around , that 's about it .
some entrances are shut down .
the obvious police presence is welcome .
it was ludicrous , the decision just a little while ago to wind back security screening in the building to save $ 2.50 .
a ludicrous decision over now .
theme of the morning : everything is true and correct right up until the minute it is n't true and correct .
on sky news meanwhile , david leyonhjelm a libertarian has not been persuaded away from his fundamental instincts and defining ideology by the change of events .
the cross bench senator has been saying since the opening of the national security conversation that he 's deeply uncomfortable with the direction of policy making .
leyonhjelm : i will not support a government that opens the door to torture .
i think george is out by himself at the moment and he needs to amend this bill .
( this is the first tranche i 've already mentioned this morning .

dreyfus signalled on radio national this morning that labor will seek to amend the force provision in tranche one to mkae sure asio agents can not actually torture people they up on counter terror investigations . )
brandis is explaining one of the provisions in the new foreign fighters legislation .
the minister for foreign affairs will have the power to designate particular regions in countries as no go ' zones .

if australians visit those regions , then they will have to prove they were there for a legitimate purpose ( visiting mum , providing aid , embarking on bona fide ' journalism whatever that means . )
that really is , after a fashion , from the point of view of the average person , something very close to a reversal of the onus of proof .
brandis prefers the more precise lawyerly construction discharging an evidential onus .
q : how does this work in the real world , though ?
do you proscribe an entire area , a particular area of the country ?
brandis : my view is it is a matter for my colleague the minister for foreign affairs , of course in my view , proscribed areas should be quite narrowly defined .
we are not talking about proscribing countries , for example , as has sometimes been said .
just a note .
this attorney-general is of course the same attorney-general who up until very recently was proselytising the virtue of freedom .
free speech .
freedom to be bigots .
nasty big government , regulating our speech , our thoughts .
a travesty .
yes , we were all here for that period .
it was moderately unforgettable actually .
now it seems big government has its uses .
( remember my opening observation : everything in canberra is true right up until the moment when it is n't . )

brandis is keen to tell his host chris uhlmann that despite his government 's intentions to significantly expand state power and the power of intelligence agenices he 's still the same old free-speech-small-government george .
the coalition has in its dna a sus of state power and a sus of over-mighty government .
we have been very , very careful to ensure that in giving the police and the security agencies the powers they need to keep australians safe , we have not overreached .

i have , as the attorney-general , approached this task with the attitude that those who wish to expand the power of the state need to make the case as to why that is necessary and i have approached it in a very careful manner as befits someone who is sus of state power .
brandis is coming over all keynsian , another oddity to add to this morning 's oddity list .
john maynard keynes famously noted that when the facts changed , he changed his mind .
brandis : this is a new environment .
it 's a different environment from when the criminal law about terrorism was last reformed in 2005 .
i think the australian people expect us to do what is necessary to keep the community safe .
not to overreach but to do what is necessary to keep the community safe .
michelle ainsworth ( @ ainswort ) coming up @ twitterid talks to ag george brandis about new terrorism laws @ twitterid studios at twenty paces .
dreyfus in the radio national cubby hole , and brandis up in the am studio .
brandis : there is no reversal of the onus of proof at all .
( over . )
is this man mad ?
the shadow attorney-general , mark dreyfus , is being interviewed right now on radio national breakfast by fran kelly .
we ca n't sign off on this bill until we 've seen it .
( imagine actually wanting to read something .
he 's speaking of the as-yet unsighted foreign fighters bill , due to be introduced to parliament on wednesday . )
dreyfus points out the government has been talking about this package for some months but there is still no exposure draft in the public domain .
dreyfus is also flagging a simple amendment to the first tranche of national security legislation , which is already in the parliament .

this first tranche expands asio 's surveillance powers over computers and computer networks , criminalises unauthorised disclosure ( and publication ) of intelligence material and allows asio agents to use force during operations .
the force provision has led critics of the bill to say this will allow asio agents to torture people they up for counter terrorism questioning .
dreyfus says it 's important to remove this risk .
he thinks an amendment in order .
let 's put it beyond doubt .
good morning everyone and welcome to another parliamentary week .
it 's delightful to be back with you .
the break has felt longer than only two weeks .
in the time since we were last together on politics live , there 's been a significant intensification of the national security theme .

the terror threat alert level has been increased ; we 've committed troops and assets to iraq ( ahead of every other major power in the world , bar the united states ) ; the police and asio have been busting down some doors in brisbane and sydney and in the middle of all that , tony abbott zipped up north for a visit to north arnhem land .
( i 've linked you there to gabrielle chan 's account of the visit please read it if you have n't , the lady is a truth seeker . )
the focal point of today is expected to be a national security update abbott provides to the house .
tomorrow , both cabinet and the coalition partyroom will sign off on another tranche of national security legislation .
the attorney-general george brandis was out and about over the weekend attempting to lay the groundwork for that package .

after signalling very clearly earlier in the year the government was considering reversing the onus of proof to make it easier to prosecute fighters returning from syria and iraq , brandis is now saying that of course there will be no reversal of the onus of proof that would be a completely mad idea how on earth did everyone come up with that ?
confused ?
well , do n't be .
that 's just how things in post truth post fact canberra tend to roll everything is absolutely true right up until the moment where it is n't .
abbott himself will be out of the country when the new package hits the parliament .
he 'll be winging his way to new york tomorrow , where he 'll be part of a un security council special session convened by barack obama .
this session is expected to deal with the domestic security risks posed by returning foreign fighters .
now tardy of me .
i 've tipped my hat to all of you , but neglected the man with the camera .
good morning to my partner in blogue crime mike bowers who is opening the sitting week in full tilt metaphor alert .
look at this absolute gem .
a long exposure catches the erratic flight of seagulls over parliament house flag on sunday evening , 22nd september 2014 .
parliament resumes this week for a two week sitting .
mike bowers for guardian australia bowers/mike bowers for guardian australia erratic flight will doubtless characterise the political week .
do fly erratically with us .
we have so much to talk about .
the politics live comments thread is wide open for your business , so get in there , loud and proud .
if you 'd like to yap to us on the twitters , i 'm there @ twitterid and bowers is there @ twitterid

bulletin.text: Tony Abbott addresses MPs in Canberra for the first time since Australia's terror threat alert level was raised. All the developments from Canberra, live.
